dc:description: SLC26A2 was first associated with autosomal recessive multiple epiphyseal dysplasia as early as 1999 (Superti-Furga et al., PMID: 10465113). Clinical features of this disorder include scoliosis, joint pain, and malformations of the hands, feet, and knees (GeneReviews, Bonafé et al., 2014). However, radiographic analysis and histopathology are also important in arriving at a diagnosis. At least 11 unique variants (including missense, splice site, and frameshift variants) have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and experimental data. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least 9 probands in 8 publications (PMID: 10465113, 12525546, 20592910, 20525296, 24598000, 21922596, 21077204, 23613459). Variants in this gene segregated with disease in 3 additional family members. More evidence is available in the literature, but the maximum score for genetic evidence has been reached. Of note, variants in this gene have also been shown to cause diastrophic dysplasia, atelosteogenesis type 2, and achondrogenesis type 1B, which comprise a spectrum of phenotypes (depending on level of residual sulfate transport) and have been definitively associated with SLC26A2. This gene-disease association is supported by expression studies and in vitro functional assays. In summary, SLC26A2 is definitively associated with autosomal recessive multiple epiphyseal dysplasia. This curation was approved by the Skeletal Disorders Gene Curation Expert Panel (GCEP) on 4/6/2020.

evidence.rdfs:label: Syvanen proband
evidence.detectionMethod: SLC26A2 only was sequenced, but the method was not specified.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
According to the authors, “clinical and radiographic findings were regarded more compatible with rMED than DTD.”  Ultrasound at 17 weeks showed bilateral clubfoot deformity and short femora. Birth length was 49 cm (-0.9 SD). Had clubfeet, ulnar deviation of both wrists, and mild micrognathia. All limbs appeared slightly short. Cystic swelling of the earlobes developed at 1 month. Bilateral congenital patellar dislocation. 
        At 10 years, valgus knees on both sides. Limited extension at elbows and ankles (bilateral). Radiographs showed small epiphyses and double-layered patella.

evidence.rdfs:label: Cho proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Presented with a foot deformity which was first noticed at 3 yr. Height was 131 cm (42nd percentile). Short fingers and thumbs. Knees and ankles in valgus alignment. Adducted forefeet. Radiographs showed small, dysplastic epiphyses (knees, hips, ankles, wrists), short and flat epiphyses of metacarpals and phalanges with premature closure at the proximal and middle phalanges of both hands (resulting in brachydactyly), and double-layered patellae. Forefoot adduction was caused by deformed medial cuneiform bones and twisted metatarsals.

evidence.dc:description: Upgraded by 0.5 points based on evidence from Karniski et al. (PMID: 15294877) demonstrating that this variant retains only partial function in both Xenopus oocytes and mammalian HEK-293 cells. The variant was expressed along the plasma membrane, but the amount of protein expressed on the cell surface was significantly lower and rates of transport were reduced compared to wild type.

evidence.rdfs:label: Hinrichs proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Presented with joint pain, swelling, and habitual dislocation of the patella on both sides. Had an Ali Krogius procedure at age 5. 170 cm tall (no disproportion). Mild lumbar scoliosis and pectus carinatum. Extension deficit of both elbow joints. Limited protonation. Flexion deficit of the MP joints. Reduced range of motion in the hip joints. Both knees had valgus angulations. Slight synovial swelling on both sides. Instable femorotibial and patellofemoral joints. Pes valgus and planus on both sides. Shortened third toe.

evidence.dc:description: Decision to move to DTD as phenotype was too severe for rMED.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient II
evidence.detectionMethod: Candidate gene sequencing only (method not specified otherwise)
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: At birth, had cleft palate, small jaw, short limbs and length, spontaneous palmar ulnar deviation and underdeveloped thumbs, abnormally shaped femoral heads, and kyphosis with underdeveloped C4. Developed severe progressive scoliosis by 2 yo. At 5 yo, height was 98 cm (-3.0 SD) and weight was 19 kg (0 SD). Stiff ankles but no clubfoot. Valgus deformity in knees, joint stiffness in upper limbs, contractures in third fingers, thick/low-set earlobes. Broad metaphyses, elbow contractures, and bilateral laterally displaced double layer patellae.

evidence.dc:description: Upgraded by 0.5 points based on evidence from Karniski et al. (PMID: 15294877) demonstrating that this variant retains only partial function in both Xenopus oocytes and mammalian HEK-293 cells. The variant was expressed along the plasma membrane, but the amount of protein expressed on the cell surface was significantly lower and rates of transport were reduced compared to wild type.

evidence.rdfs:label: Superti-Furga 1999 proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: At birth, had club foot and hip dysplasia. As an adult, had a discrepancy in leg length, possibly from early ankle and foot surgery. Had brachydactyly, clinodactyly of the 5th finger, mild valgus deformity at the knees, shortening of 1st toe, adduction of the foot with wide spacing between 1st and 2nd toes, shortening of metacarpals and middle phalanges, and double-layered patella. Left convex scoliosis in lumbar region. Bowed lower arms and limited elbow flexion. Limited mobility of index fingers. Pain in hips, knees and feet. Normal stature (180 cm).

evidence.rdfs:label: ESDN-00129
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Diagnosis on referral was progressive pseudorheumatoid dysplasia, however following review by the panel this proband was diagnosed with rMED. Radiographs were not published.

evidence.dc:description: Not scored because of low confidence in the variants. Additionally, there appeared to be other factors contributing to short stature in other family members like the mother.

evidence.rdfs:label: Barreda-Bonis proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: At birth, had bilateral skewfoot, rhizomelic shortening of extremities, and micrognathia with a high-arched palate. Referred for disproportionate short stature at 16 mo. At her last visit (14.8 yr), height was 149.5 cm. Advanced bone age.

evidence.dc:description: Decision to move to DTD curation as phenotype was too severe for rMED.

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 1
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Unequal leg lengths were first noticed at 6 yo. Abnormal gait and limping were noted at 9 yo. Had right hip arthroplasty and resection of cartilago acetabularis for limited rotation of the right leg. Chronic synovitis. Lump in the left femoribus internus. Limited flexion-extension of the left leg. Height: 138 cm. Brachydactyly, bilateral skewfoot, lumbosacral scoliosis. Limited movement of both hips.

evidence.rdfs:label: Makitie patient 6
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Diagnosed with rMED at 3 years old. Radiographic findings consistent with MED. Had bilateral clubfoot but no spinal deformity or contractures. At 2 months, had swollen ears and aspirations, but no residual deformity. Z-score for height was -1.98 at birth and -2.47 at 6 yr.

member.rdfs:label: Czarny-Ratajczak patient 1
member.phenotypeFreeText: At 42 yo, height was 166 cm. Waddling gait and increasing hip pain since 3 yo. Brachydactyly, proximally placed thumbs, and clinodactyly of the 5th fingers. Limited movement of the big joints worsened with age. During the 2nd decade of life, had progressive flexion contractures of the hip and elbow joints. Used crutches at 23 yr. Radiographs at 3 yr showed flattened proximal femoral epiphyses, shortened femoral necks, platyspondyly w/ irregular vertebral plates, and scoliosis. Multilayered patellae and shortened metacarpals. Early onset progressive osteoarthritis.

evidence.dc:description: Upgraded by 0.5 points based on evidence from Karniski et al. (PMID: 15294877) demonstrating that the p.A715V variant retains only partial function in both Xenopus oocytes and mammalian HEK-293 cells. The variant was expressed along the plasma membrane, but the amount of protein expressed on the cell surface was significantly lower and rates of transport were reduced compared to wild type.

evidence.rdfs:label: Makitie patient 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Diagnosed with rMED at age 8. Was noted to have mild thoracal scoliosis and contractures in some fingers. At age 10, his Z-score for height was -1.42

evidence.rdfs:label: Patient 7
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Diagnosed with skeletal dysplasia at 5 yo. Primary complaint was joint pain. Height was 130 cm (10th centile). Radiographs of hands showed cone-shaped epiphyses. Proximal femoral epiphyses were small and less rounded than usual.

evidence.dc:description: Not scored due to low confidence in the p.V118E variant.

evidence.rdfs:label: Hauer proband
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Disproportionate short stature (-3.6 SD), scoliosis, pectus excavatum, pes planus, coxa vara.

evidence.dc:description: In situ hybridization and immunostaining detected SLC26A2 mRNA in developing fetal hyaline cartilage and adult bronchial cartilage.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression in human cartilage

evidence.dc:description: In situ hybridization showed that Slc26a2 was expressed in the limbs, craniofacial regions, and lumbosacral spine of mouse embryos at day 14.5.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression in mouse embryos

evidence.dc:description: Immunohistochemistry showed that Slc26a2 was expressed in the chondrocytes of freshly isolated mouse articular cartilage explants.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression in mouse articular cartilage

evidence.dc:description: Decreased sulfate transport has been demonstrated to be a mechanism for variants associated with rMED (and other disorders of the SLC26A2 spectrum) (PMID: 15294877).
evidence.rdfs:label: Sulfate uptake

evidence.dc:description: shRNA knockdown of Slc26a2 caused decreased proliferation of chondrocytes (differentiated from mouse progenitor mesenchymal cells) and reduced basal proteoglycan synthesis, possibly by inhibiting the effect of IGF-1 on synthesis.
evidence.rdfs:label: shRNA knockdown
